Fields.DialogueText: Delhi? The Morganas are here, so why haven't you opened fire yet?
... Quiet, please. I need to concentrate. The moment is almost here.
What moment?
I have my eye on a particular Morgana, but it is not quite in range yet. I am holding my fire until the time is right.
I see. But we're running out of time. They're almost on top of us now.
Patience. Letting fear overcome you in battle will not help you reach victory.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as you are certain that you'll be able to kill that Morgana when the moment arrives.
But how will you know when is the perfect opportunity to strike?
I'm just a little nervous about the battle.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not worry. I have mastered the art of the hunt. Once it enters my territory, it will not escape.
I watch the flap of fabric in the wind, the pitch of the deck in the waves. The smallest factor can make all the difference.
I understand. There is always a chance that the fight will end badly. But we must maintain a sense of dignity to the end, as it gives all hope to continue.
You almost ready, Delhi?
Yes, it's... now!
Great shot! You really did a number on it.
Thanks. Now let's get into the fray.
No more taking your time?
I could afford it before. But now that they're at close quarters, I need to help keep my companions afloat.
@BATTLE
Hi, Delhi!
Oh, Captain! You startled me!
Really engrossed in your book, huh? What happened to that alert huntress?
That was in battle. This is not.
Well, that's fine. We can all use some time to enjoy our pursuits. So, what are you reading?
... A book.
I can see that that is most certainly a book. I was just wondering what sort of book it is you were reading.
Nothing of importance. Can I go now?
Delhi, why do you seem nervous?
This talk is just making me uncomfortable. Can't I just be alone for a while?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry. I just thought we could try to be friends.
I understand. I'll leave you in peace.
All right, but we're all here to help if you feel alone, all right?

Fields.DialogueText: No, I am sorry. I just... have trouble with relationships outside of battle.
Captain! I... still enjoyed talking to you.
Thanks. I will keep that in mind.
Well, I'll be going now.
Captain... I was reading a rendition of the Mahābhārata.
Thanks for sharing, Delhi.
You're welcome.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. Sorry I took away from your quiet time.
No problem, Captain. I... enjoyed our conversation. In any case, we need to get on the move, now!
@BATTLE
Everyone, to your stations! We cannot allow these Morganas to escape!
@BATTLE
That was a rough battle, huh, Delhi?
Mmm, yes...
What's wrong?
Nothing. I just need to resew and iron part of my uniform.
Oh, right. It must have gotten damaged in the brawl.
Yes, but I need to fix it before I do anything else now.
You sure? You don't need to work on it immediately, you know?
But I do. A soldier must stay properly attired at all times to set a good example for the troops.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need any help with the repairs?
Keep in mind that they'll just get ripped again in the next battle, though.
Is it really so important to worry about your clothes?

Fields.DialogueText: If you don't mind, that would be nice. Thank you.
So? Just as with this war, we must constantly work to build and rebuild our treasures, no matter how many times they are lost or destroyed.
It is not that important in the large scale of things. Nevertheless, it is an important part of the process, like everything else. And all pieces must work for the ultimate goal to succeed.
Well, I was going to point out that some of the others were planning to have a party, if you're interested.
I know, but I need to attend to other duties first. Maybe later.
Well... have fun.
You, too.
That should be good for the moment.
Those were some pretty interesting exercises. What sort of style are they?
A variety of martial arts from East Asia, primarily focused around the concept of shastra vidya.
That's interesting. You were really amazing with those moves. Those Morganas don't stand a chance, do they?
Thank you. Though this is for more than simply the war.
What do you mean?
These exercises help me find a sense of spiritual peace, which I can hold in my heart in the midst of war.
I see. I can see why that would be helpful.
Technology and culture may change the course of war again and again, but the values of the soul are eternal.

Fields.MenuText: What does "shastra vidya" mean?
I imagine that it helps with staying in shape as well.
That looks pretty tricky.

Fields.DialogueText: It means "weapon-knowledge." Technically, it refers to knowing how to use weapons, but more than that, it symbolizes the duality of power and wisdom.
Yes, it does. I love using it to keep myself healthy and ready for battle.
The individual steps can be rather confusing at times, but the important thing is to master the flow of the art. Then the trial becomes a dance of wonder.
Say, do you think you might be willing to teach the art to others? I'm sure there are lots of people who would like to learn.
I don't know. I can't imagine too many people would really be interested in my hobbies.
I am.
I'll think about it.
All right. For now, let's apply that spirit to the battlefield.
@BATTLE
These Morganas seem to be getting more sophisticated every day. Delhi, we need some covering fire!
Hold on, I'm almost done with these notes.
Notes?
I wanted to record my observations of the Morganas. That latest tactic they used was quite innovative, you know.
I'd be a little more impressed if they weren't trying to kill us right now.
Well, that is an issue, but we should not get discouraged. Rather, we should be incentivized.
To fight harder? You have a point with that.
Not just that. Incentive for us to match them in advances.
Oh, I get it - you want to replicate their technology?
Yes. They are a worthy opponent in battle, so it would be wise to pay attention to their strengths and what we can learn from them.

Fields.MenuText: But how will we copy their technologies?
Just make sure you don't lose focus on the battle right now.
You seem to be rather admiring of them, despite what they have done.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not sure myself. But if we all work together, surely we will find the answers we need.
Right! I'm sorry about that.
There can be no hate in battle, only joy that we are all children of the world. Hopefully one day we can understand each other's hearts and seek common peace. Until then, the war goes on.
Well, are you about finished with the notes?
Yes. There are a few interesting details I noticed...
We can talk about those later. Can you give us a hand?
I'm on it. They won't get any further!
That's the spirit! Let's end this battle on our terms.
@BATTLE
Delhi, what has you so focused right now?
I sensed something coming. I'm pretty sure it's Morganas. We should ambush them before they ambush us.
@BATTLE
Victory!
Yes, the Morganas were no match against our combined power.
We sure make a good team, huh?
We do, all of us. Well... I'll be on my way, then.
Where are you going? There's going to be a party.
Thanks, but I think I'll decline. I don't really drink, so I wouldn't have much to do there.
There's not just going to be alcohol, you know. It's also a chance to talk with some of the crew.
I already talked to them during the battle. There's no need to do anything further now.

Fields.MenuText: Will you be all right, being alone like this?
If you're staying out, I'll keep you company.
A friendship isn't something you can turn on and off. Every moment counts.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, of course.
You don't have to do that.
You have a good point. It's just... it doesn't come easily to me.
...Maybe I'll check things out, just for a little bit.
Great! Come on, let's get this celebration started for our mighty heroines!
I was really just thinking of staying on the sidelines... but all right.
Don't worry. You made it through the battle, so this can't be that hard, right?
Yeah... sure.
Still, I wish you would come with us.
No, I insist. If that's fine with you.
Mmm, what's cooking in here?
I made a batch of kachori, a special snack from my namesake city.
Neat. Mind if I have a taste?
Sure, but I must warn you...
Yow! Hot!
They have a bit of a kick to them.
I noticed. Well, aside from my overwhelming need for water, it was pretty tasty.
I'm glad that you like it. I just had a craving for some, so I decided to make them myself.
You sure made a bunch, though.
Well, I was thinking that this could be distributed amongst the fleet. Would you mind helping out with that, please?
Sure. Let's go.
"Let us...?"
They were your creation, so I thought you would want to help give them out.
There is no need to give me the credit for it. I just want the crew to enjoy the food.

Fields.MenuText: I might need your help telling the crew what to expect, in terms of spiciness.
They'll enjoy the food even more if they can learn about its history from you.
You don't have to come if you don't want to. I just thought it would be more fun to do it together.

Fields.DialogueText: You have a point there. I might also want to let them know the specific ingredients in case of allergies.
... You're right. I suppose knowledge of the food's history could better the experience of tasting it.
Well... I suppose that could be nice. It can be tough doing things alone.
All right, I'll come.
Glad to hear it. Let's get started – once we fry some Morganas, that is.
@BATTLE
Hiyah!
Whoa, watch it, Delhi! You almost skewered me there!
Sorry! Just practicing with these spears.
Well, you're pretty good with them, I have to say. Good enough to make a human – or Morgana – kebab.
Why, thank you. It is a Delhi tradition, after all.
To use spears in battle?
Well, there's that, but I meant the kebabs. It, and many other customs, have spread across the wind through the Empire, from South America to Africa to the islands in the Pacific.
That's one benefit of the cultural exchange, I guess.
Yes, one of the virtues of our pact. I just wish that other aspects were also given respectful attention.

Fields.MenuText: Times are changing. People will learn to see the full vibrancy of the world, you'll see.
Every encounter has its consequences, both good and bad. But each interaction helps move the world forward.
It's all a matter of finding a way to reach their hearts.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I too have high hopes for the future. It rests on us to make those dreams advance.
You're right. Nothing in this world is perfect, but perhaps that is what gives life its beauty when we experience it in full.
I know. Someone has to take that step, and understand them enough to make the right connection. It's hard, but I'm making my way there, slowly.
Say, I also made some edible kebabs. Care to have some?
Don't mind if I do! But first we need to avoid becoming the main course ourselves!
Ah, those Morganas certainly know how to spoil an appetite.
@BATTLE
You in here, Delhi?
Yes, I was just refurbishing - making space for a house of worship.
Oh? For what religion?
Baha'i. Although, with the universality of the faith, the house will be open to worship of all kinds.
Interesting. Still, you'll likely need to convince the crew of its merit.
Always a challenge, I know. But right now, I'll have to politely ask you to vacate the room. The tradition is that no words can be spoken inside other than those of a faith.
I see. Can we continue our conversation outside it?
Of course. I had about reached a good stopping point anyway.
That's good. I have to say, I couldn't see that far in, but I liked that lotus design in the back.
Ah, that was my own personal touch. Other than that, though, I want this to be a place where people can find unity together.

Fields.MenuText: Was this inspired by your home city?
You seem really open to different ideas.
The idea of universal harmony must be important to you.

Fields.DialogueText: No, but it is growing in the region. I believe it is a solace to humankind, and that is enough for me.
I love learning new things, and I enjoy helping others gain appreciation for other cultures and concepts as well.
Indeed. I feel that it is the key to peace in the world. If we can all see that we are chosen for the mission of living in this world together, we can change the world.
Well, I look forward to checking out the services there.
Thanks. I just hope the crew will be interested.
I'm sure they will be, if you can talk to them and show how passionate you are about the idea.
I'll try.
That's all we can do in the end. For now, let's protect this sanctuary, and the fleet, from that raiding party.
May the forces of might and harmony lead us to victory once more.
@BATTLE
Delhi, there you – *cough*! What's with this smoke?!
Ah, I was sampling one of my tobacco pipes, straight from India.
It's rather... strong.
Yes, but it grows on you.
I've heard that it can be bad for your health.
We risk our lives every day out here, don't we? This is just one more risk for me.
And yet you refuse to drink alcohol.
That vile drink taints the mind. All things die one way or another, but I will at least know my mind is spiritually pure.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just worried that this could become a fire hazard on board.
Not everyone likes the smoke, you know.
Even so, I'd rather see you avoid hurting your long-term health. You stay in shape so well otherwise.

Fields.DialogueText: You have a good point. I'm constantly on guard.
I know. Fortunately, I prefer smoking on my own.
If I can deal with fire, a little smoke won't kill me. But I do appreciate your concern, Captain.
Nevertheless, I'll try to limit my use of tobacco to avoid causing waves. I have a limited stock, so I might as well save it for special occasions.
Thanks. Though you might not be the only smoker aboard. I can smell more of it even now.
That's another smoke entirely... the kind that intends to kill you directly.
You're right. Let's get ready for battle.
Yes. And then I can have a celebratory smoke afterward.
@BATTLE
Hello, Delhi. Doing some cotton weaving, I see.
Yes. I value being self-sufficient, so I thought I might make some cotton fabric of my own.
A good idea. Using some styles from India?
Not at the moment. I did a few in those styles earlier, but right now I am using a method from my hometown of Elswick.
Elswick? Oh, you mean where you were constructed in England. I sometimes forget that you're British.
Well, it runs in the family. My two sisters are partially of New Zealand and South African heritage.
The empire where the sun never sets.
Yes, though there has been some tension with some of the colonies of late.
I've heard about that. What are your thoughts on the whole issue?
...Nations such as India yearn to find their own path, and I wish them the best. But I feel that we can also find greater purpose together. Fortunately, there might be a solution.
What do you mean?
The ships. I embody both Mother England and the heart of India. It is my dream that we can serve as a link for different cultures to understand and appreciate each other.

Fields.MenuText: That is a beautiful idea you have. I just hope it works.
Even if you help build cultural awareness, there's still the matter of past grudges.
If you want that idea to work, you'll have to speak up.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. But hope is not enough. We must have faith, and then act to make the dream coalesce.
Ah, yes, violence often begets violence later on, does it not? But for every war, there is also a chance to make peace.
You're right. Silence will not make a difference.
It looks like that sweater is coming along well.
Yes, it's almost done. I just wish that cotton were more waterproof.
Me too. With all these attacks day and night, it seems like we're always on the verge of getting all wet.
@BATTLE
It will work out. I'm sure of it.
Hmm... not much in this one either.
What are you looking at, Delhi?
Oh, just some of the recent news reports about the Morganas. But they're a little disappointing.
Why? Are they pushing us back?
Not that. It's just that the reports are rather dry and only focus on the results.
Well, that's to be expected. What were you hoping for?
I wanted to see if anyone had theories or insight on the Morganas' motives. But everyone seems focused on the short term.
Well, many of our battles have been close. Most of the eyewitnesses are likely more preoccupied with staying alive.
True. Still, a true warrior always fights on three battlefields - in the past of memories, in the present trial, and in the future through reflection.

Fields.MenuText: The war is still young. It will take time for people to publish their findings.
Not everyone is as skilled as you are.
Sometimes you have to be the first person to stand up and do something for things to move forward.

Fields.DialogueText: You're probably right. I just wish we knew more about the Morganas right now. Every bit of knowledge counts in the end.
Nonsense. I believe that everyone has great potential. Perhaps not on the same path as myself, but a noble one nevertheless, if they take the first steps.
I didn't think about it that way. It means I'd have to probably give a speech or something, but... it would be worth it, for all of us.
Maybe I'll just publish a report myself. I have been gathering data during our engagements, after all.
That sounds great. And you're going to get another chance to observe and interact with them in a jiffy.
If only they could hold still more often for me to take closer notes...
@BATTLE
That's an interesting dance you're doing there.
Thanks! Care to join in? It's pretty easy once you get the hang of it.
Sure. What dance is this, anyway?
It's called the "Dance of the Little Shield." It has a military feel to it, does it not?
You're right, I can see what you mean. Is this from India?
No, this originates from the Zulus. My sister Durban taught it to me.
It sounds as if the two of you get along well.
We do. Every time I do one of these dances, I think of her.

Fields.MenuText: It's good to have loved ones you can share things with.
Do you know anything else about the Zulus?
You've sure traveled around a lot.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. It's easy to share things with family. Learning to share things with others can be more difficult.
Yes, quite a lot. Durban and I have spoken extensively on their religious practices.
It's what I love to do. A traveler is a citizen of all worlds, and can synthesize their experiences to better understand the universe.
Whew! This dance is tricky!
But you've done an admirable job for your first try.
Thanks. As far as traditions go, this is an interesting one.
Yes. It's too bad that so many of them are dismissed as unimportant by others.
Then it's up to you to ensure they aren't forgotten.
You're right.
In any case, hopefully that war dance will prepare us for this next barrage.
@BATTLE
Delhi? Delhi?
Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't notice you.
I can see that. Sorry I disturbed you.
That's perfectly all right. It's my own fault. True meditation serves not to escape from the world, but to better connect with it.
Ah, so that's what you were doing. You looked very regal in your meditation pose.
Well, thank you. This is a way for me to relax outside of battle.
Typically, I have more difficulty relaxing during battle.
Such is the curse of karma on warriors, I am afraid. The better we become in the thick of battle, the harder it is for us to acclimate ourselves to peaceful days.

Fields.MenuText: But if you truly desire peace, that has to mean something, right?
It's a high price, but if that's what it takes for us to defend everyone, we'll have to learn to live with it.
From witnessing you and your hobbies, I think you already have a good knack for non-fighting activities.

Fields.DialogueText: It does. True soldiers find strength from their desire for peace, as it gives them something to protect and work toward.
I suppose so. Maybe someday, though, we can finally bring an end to all of this fighting for good.
Thank you. I try to keep myself busy and happy. It's the social areas where I have the most difficulty.
Well, you're a smart and determined person, Delhi. I'm sure you'll figure something out.
You're right. I just need to think about things a little longer.
Just save the meditating for later. These Morganas aren't the patient sort.
@BATTLE
La de da! A little more saffron and we're set.
You've really gone to work with the kitchen, haven't you?
Yes! I decided to make a little feast based on the festival down under in Fremantle.
Great. What's on the menu?
Sardines.
And...?
More sardines!
So, sardines are the theme.
Precisely. Esplanade Park's yearly celebration features solely sardines.
How many sardine dishes can a festival have?
Well, there are sardine salads, sardine paellas, sardines and chips...
I get the point.

Fields.MenuText: When is the festival held?
You certainly made a lot of food to go around.
Why sardines in particular?

Fields.DialogueText: I forget, but it doesn't really matter. Any day is good for a party.
I did my best. I want there to be enough for the whole crew. No one should feel left out.
I suppose I have a bit of a personal attachment to sardines, although I'm not sure why.
Well, it looks like the food's about ready.
Indeed. Would you round the others up while I tend to the kitchen?
It sounds like you're trying to weasel out of being part of the party yourself.
Maybe...
Look, let's talk this out after the upcoming battle. Hopefully breaking this lot will be like smashing cans.
@BATTLE
There you go, into the nice, soft dirt by the water's side. May you grow proud and strong.
That's a nice garden you have budding here, Delhi. You certainly have a green thumb.
Why, thank you. I'm trying to recreate a Mughal-style garden from India.
I see. How's that coming along?
Pretty well, but I've run into one key issue.
What's that?
The problem is that gardens in India don't have to deal with daily earthquakes – or the equivalent, that is. The pools keep splashing out of control, and I don't know what to do.
I see. That's a tricky problem.
Yes, and I was really looking forward to this. The gardens always have a sense of serenity and hope to them, much like our efforts to safeguard the world.

Fields.MenuText: You could always try to change up the design a little, to adjust to the circumstances.
I guess you'll just have to keep replenishing the garden every time something happens.
Maybe some of the others have some ideas they could share?

Fields.DialogueText: That's it! Even the first emperors had to adjust their plans to India's new environments. I'm sure they won't mind a few changes.
You're right, it can't be helped. I'm sure such behavior will instill discipline.
Good idea. I'm sure some of them have their own unique visions of how to handle the gardens. ...Do you think you could talk with them, please?
Anyway, this is all very nice. I see you have some food growing as well.
Of course. Self-sufficiency is important, after all.
Maybe we should start a community garden amongst the ships.
That sounds nice!
On the other hand, it means one more thing to keep out of the Morganas' sights.
We'll work it out, you'll see. They don't stand a chance.
@BATTLE
All right, all right.
Hey, Delhi, I was wondering...
Yes? Just give me one second to finish up my exercises, and then I'll be with you.
Actually, that's what I wanted to ask you about again.
Again? What do you mean by that?
Do you think you could teach me?
Teach you my martial arts techniques?
Exactly. Do you mind me learning them?
No, not at all. I could direct you to some useful books, but I don't know if I could properly guide you.
On the contrary. I have full faith in your instruction capabilities.
Yes, but... why do you want to learn from me in particular?

Fields.MenuText: Because I see how you put all your strength into protecting everyone. I want to become like that too.
Think of this as a mutually beneficial agreement. You help me become stronger, and I help you open up socially in the process.
I admire your diligence, and I think that will suit you well as a teacher.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, everyone is a hero in their own way in war. Even the Morganas are, to themselves. But I can teach you skills so you do not have to die as one.
Ah, I suppose that could be of some benefit.
You may be right. But as they say, you never know until the battle begins.
So, will you, please?
Very well. I agree. I will be your master and not rest until you are my equal in battle.
Thanks. I look forward to studying under you.
In that case, let's start the exercises from the top.
But you said that you were nearly done.
That was before. A soldier never rests.
Well, let's holding off on the training until we do some live-fire work against the Morganas.
@BATTLE
What's cooking this time?
Baking, actually. Coconut tarts and pineapple bread, my own special recipe.
Great. Looks like our surplus garden is coming in handy.
It is! I like making my own bread. It has its own special feel to it.
More of your self-sufficiency plan?
Partially, but I also learned to appreciate homemade pastries when I visited the Guianas.
Well, I can't wait to taste it when it's done.
You won't have to wait much longer. The bread should be properly baked in just a few...
*ALARM*
Now, of all times?
You know the Morganas never give us the civility of a notice for their arrival. We have to do what we can.
But what do I do now? If I take it now, it will be underdone. But otherwise the bread will be toasted!

Fields.MenuText: Toast has its own fine quality to it.
Let's wrap up the battle quick, then, so we can get back in time.
Just calm down and think this through. You have a sharp mind, so what's the plan?

Fields.DialogueText: It would make for an interesting change of pace. Assuming we can digest it, that is.
You're right. If we're swift with our movements, we might be able to save the dish.
That's right. All right, I think I've got this handled.
I'm ready. Let me at them.
Right behind you. But let's be careful. These Morganas look packed with enough ammunition to smoke us to a crisp ourselves.
@BATTLE
All right, Captain, it's time for our first practice.
All right, I'm ready. What do you have for me?
We'll do a few laps around the ship.
Doesn't sound too hard...
Never make that comment to your trainer.
Nuts.
Now, as I was about to add, you will be doing so while wearing this.
Armor?
Mirror armor, or char-aina, to use the proper terminology.
And you want me to run around with it?
It will be good for you. It's always best if we are properly fitted out for battle. Now come on, try it on!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure it will be that effective in battle.
Delhi, it's too much to ask me to jog in this!
The reflective nature on this coat is a little over the top. It's blinding.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps not, but it may help a little. In war, the small things we do can have great import.
Whoever said that you had to run in this?
Why, of course. How else would it help to deflect the evil eyes of those monsters out there?
All right, I've got it on. How does it look?
Splendid! I've got my own as well.
Uh, oh. I think I just spotted a Morgana.
And where there's one, there's more. Let's get a move on!
Just wait a second. I think I have the helmet on backwards.
@BATTLE
But you said...
I said we would go around the ship a few times. I never specified at what pace. Remember to listen.
Checking on the gardens?
Thriving as usual, if I do say so myself. I've hit upon a project quite by accident.
Whoa! You installed a waterfall on the ship?
A small one, at least. I was working out how to mitigate the effect of the motion of the ship on the pools, and one thing led to another.
Well, you really outdid yourself this time. And the pool looks good enough to swim in.
Perhaps it is.
Huh?
One of my regrets at Fiji was that I could not swim under some of their famous waterfalls. But these are not inland, so I can give it a go.
Wait, you're going to do it right now?
No time like the present. And it's a good way for me to inspect the water flow up close and personal.

Fields.MenuText: Shouldn't you take off that armor? You'll sink like a rock.
If you want to, go right ahead. Have fun!
I wonder if fish could live in there.

Fields.DialogueText: Think of it as an unintended strength exercise.
Thanks! I'm really excited about this.
Great idea! Fish would improve the vitality of this little paradise.
Just be careful not to hit your head diving, all right?
Don't worry, I'll be careful. Care to join me?
I'm not really dressed for the occasion.
Neither am I. Does it matter?
In the long run, I suppose not. Still, it looks as if your plans will be thwarted for the time being. A few Morganas are headed this direction.
@BATTLE
Delhi? We're reaching the contact point. But I see you're already in the midst of preparations.
Just polishing up my weapons so they serve me well through this next trial.
Let's hope the Morganas take it easy on us this time.
Don't underestimate them. Behind their masks of rage, they have the spirits of mighty forces of war and determination.
I'd just be happy if they'd do us the favor of holding still long enough for us to make some headway.
... If they did, I might hesitate.
What do you mean?
They have their own motives for this war, ones we have yet to understand.
What's wrong? You seem melancholy.
I'm just thinking about things. I'll be fine.

Fields.MenuText: I'm here if you need to talk about anything.
Let's focus on winning for now.
Thoughts travel nowhere unless you give them voice.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. Thank you, Captain.
Yes. At least there, I can find some peace in a way.
The trouble is getting the words right. It's harder than it seems at first glance.
In any case, there's no point waiting here. Let's get ready.
All right. I think I see the first of the enemy.
... Chosen, not destroyed.
Pardon?
Oh, it's nothing. Charge!
@BATTLE
There you are, Delhi. What are you doing all the way up here?
Just gazing up at the endless sky, I suppose. It's perfectly natural to look at the stars and clouds for answers.
And what sort of answers are you getting?
None at the moment. But at least it gives me something to do.
Would you like to go fishing? Some of the crew are getting rods and bait together.
I appreciate the invitation, but I'm content to stay here for the time being.
Come on, it will be fun.
I'm not sure, I worry... I might get in the way.
What do you mean?
I am first and foremost a ship, one built for war. I can connect with others on the battlefield, but off the battlefield, well... I can prove to be a hindrance.

Fields.MenuText: That's balderdash. If you limit yourself like that, you'll get nowhere. And I know you want more.
Just think of the fishing as another battle you can lead us in.
We all make mistakes, but we can forgive as well. What matters is sharing time together.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right, I do. Is it right to defy your station? Or who is to say what it is...?
Life is itself is a battle, I suppose. A fight for life, a fight for peace, a fight for answers.
...Yes, that is what ultimately counts in the end.
So, do you think you can join us? Please?
Sure.
Great! ... Then again, we might need to postpone our fishing expedition until we handle the local water hazards.
@BATTLE
I don't like this. There's supposed to be a Morgana detachment in the vicinity, and now the trail might as well have gone cold.
Not to worry. I'll get us back on the trail.
Really? It's difficult, given how the Morganas ambush us so often.
Nothing is easy in life, but this is something I have trained myself for.
But how do you plan to find them?
Little clues, here and there. A fish ten feet below, a bird's cry, the sun's shadow.
Ah, well, if you can figure it out, good. Got something?
Yes, I can lead us straight to them.
So what are we waiting for?
I just wanted to make sure I had your approval.
Why would you think you didn't have it?
The Morganas' visibility is reduced in this fog, but they will still spot us before we can see them.
I see. You're not sure if it's best to fight them in these conditions.
But if we don't, we may not get another chance. What is your command?

Fields.MenuText: Let's wait here for the moment. They're searching for us as well, remember. Let them come to us.
Move forward, but carefully. We don't want any ambushes.
Speed forward once you have a clear vector. We'll strike before they can react.

Fields.DialogueText: An astute plan. You have the keen mind of a hunter.
Right. Best to be on guard, lest the hunter become the hunted.
Understood. Let's see how they like being the ones surprised for a change.
And so the fog lifts.
And here are the Morganas, just like you predicted. You make a great tracker.
Thanks. Though I prefer the title hunter. It accounts for both the tracking and the subsequent attacking.
@BATTLE
Hello, Delhi. You seem to be doing well.
Just enjoying a little peace and quiet. There's nothing quite like having a cup of tea while reading a book.
Mind if I have a sip...?
Wait! I'll need to pour a new pitcher for you.
Why? There's plenty here.
Yes, but due to my unique... physiology, I spice up my tea.
With peppers from the east?
Sometimes, yes. But right now, that tea contains arsenic.
Arsenic?!
It has a rather delightful flavor to it, assuming you are able to survive it.
Thanks for the heads up. Just try be careful no one accidentally takes a sample.
Of course. Such a shame you can't appreciate it. This batch is straight from Devon.
Still, you might want to be careful, both with that and your cigars. Who knows how your health might respond to such influences in the future?
The karma of a soldier is entrenched in darkness. Death always comes in the end. That's part of why I'd rather keep to myself. It's easier that way.

Fields.MenuText: You're not the only person with issues and worries. But that doesn't mean that we should avoid human contact.
Rather than trying to live out your life alone, shouldn't you try to make the most of your life instead?
You can do what you like. But I don't think it would be good to risk your life unnecessarily.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I know you're right. Socialization just doesn't come easily to me.
You're right. I wouldn't want to reach the end of my life and find that I've wasted it.
A valid argument. I will try not to put myself in jeopardy needlessly.
... Thank you for talking with me. It helps me feel stronger.
You're already strong, Delhi. I see that. The crew see that. If you do decide to share yourself a bit more, there are a lot of people who would be eager to learn from you.
The thought had crossed my mind. Compared to these Morganas up ahead, socializing should be a piece of cake.
@BATTLE
We're nearly done, Delhi, so you can go if you want.
That's all right, I'm fine here with you.
You sure? I know you get uncomfortable if you're around people too long outside of battle.
Yes, but nothing is permanent. Everyone changes. I'm hopeful that I will be more comfortable around others with time.
You really have grown a lot.
Thank you. But I know I need to grow more. So, Captain, do you think you could help me?
What do you mean?
Wanderers often feel alone, going so many places but never feeling a part of any.
Delhi...
But being with you makes me feel better, no matter the situation. I think, through you, opening up is getting easier.
I'm happy to hear so, Delhi. You know I've only ever wanted what's best for you.
So, will you continue to help me? On my own, I know I'm a lost cause, but with you... I think I could improve. There are quite a lot of us aboard, after all.

Fields.MenuText: Of course, Delhi. Whatever I can do to help.
I vow that I will always be by your side, Delhi. Whatever you need, I will help provide.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. I'm glad to be fighting this war with a friend by my side.
I'm so happy to hear you say so, Captain. I... please, come to my garden if you seek respite. I'll be there.
